title: 107_s1532
content: The Act may be cited as the "Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001". Federal-State Agreements are addressed in the Act. The Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to enter agreements with the Secretary of Labor to provide emergency extended unemployment compensation to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits. States can terminate the agreement with 30 days notice. The Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide extended benefits to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits, under certain conditions such as not receiving compensation from other sources and meeting eligibility criteria. The Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide extended benefits to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits. An individual is deemed to have exhausted their rights to regular compensation under a State law when no more payments can be made or when their rights have been terminated. The weekly benefit amount for emergency extended unemployment compensation is equal to the amount of regular compensation available. The Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide extended benefits to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits. The weekly benefit amount for emergency extended unemployment compensation is equal to the amount of regular compensation available under the State law. The terms and conditions of the State law apply to claims for emergency extended unemployment compensation, with some exceptions. The Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to provide extended benefits to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits. State laws inconsistent with this Act or the Secretary's regulations do not apply. The maximum amount of emergency extended unemployment compensation for an individual is limited to the amount in their account. Governors in extended benefit periods can offer emergency extended compensation instead of regular extended benefits to eligible individuals separated from employment after September 11, 2001. The Emergency Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 2001 allows states to offer extended benefits to individuals who have exhausted regular benefits, without triggering off an extended benefit period. SEC. 3. EMERGENCY EXTENDED UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION ACCOUNT. An agreement under this Act requires a qualified State to establish an emergency extended unemployment compensation account for eligible individuals. The account amount is based on the lesser of 100 percent of total regular compensation or 13 times the individual's average weekly benefit amount. The benefit amount for the benefit year is subject to reduction for extended benefits received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970. No emergency extended unemployment compensation shall be payable before specific dates outlined in the Act. The benefit amount for the benefit year may be reduced for extended benefits received under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970, with specific eligibility dates outlined in the Act. SEC. 4. PAYMENTS TO STATES WITH AGREEMENTS FOR EMERGENCY EXTENDED UNEMPLOYMENT COMPENSATION. Payments to states with agreements for emergency extended unemployment compensation shall be equal to 100 percent of the compensation paid to individuals under the agreement. States will not receive payment for compensation already reimbursed under other federal laws. The amount payable to each state with an agreement will be determined accordingly. The Secretary will determine the payments to states with agreements for emergency extended unemployment compensation, based on estimates for each calendar month. These estimates may be adjusted for any over or underpayments in prior months, using agreed-upon methods between the Secretary and the state agency. SEC. 5. FINANCING PROVISIONS. The extended unemployment compensation accounts in the Unemployment Trust Fund will be used to make payments to States with agreements under this Act. The Secretary will certify payments to States, and the Treasury will make payments to States accordingly. Appropriations are authorized from the employment security administration account to assist States. Appropriations are authorized from the employment security administration account to assist States in meeting the costs of administration of agreements under this Act. Additionally, funds are authorized to be appropriated from the general fund of the Treasury to the extended unemployment compensation account for making payments under this section. Amounts appropriated under section 3309(a)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 do not need to be repaid. SEC. 6. FRAUD AND OVERPAYMENTS. Individuals who knowingly make false statements or fail to disclose material facts to receive emergency extended unemployment compensation they are not entitled to will be ineligible for further benefits. They will also be required to repay any amounts received improperly. The State agency may waive repayment of emergency extended unemployment benefits if it was not the individual's fault and repayment would be unfair. The agency can recover repayments by deducting from future benefits under this Act or other federal laws. The State agency may waive repayment of emergency extended unemployment benefits if it was not the individual's fault and repayment would be unfair. Repayment or deductions will only occur after a fair hearing and final determination. Any State agency decision can be reviewed in the same manner as under the State unemployment compensation law. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. The terms related to compensation and eligibility under the Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 are defined. An individual's period of eligibility is determined by the State's qualification status. A "qualified state" is one that has experienced a major disaster or emergency declared by the President before October 1, 2001. The Federal-State Extended Unemployment Compensation Act of 1970 defines compensation and eligibility terms. A "qualified state" is determined by experiencing a major disaster or emergency declared by the President before October 1, 2001. States must meet specific criteria to maintain qualified status. The Secretary determines when a State's unemployment rate is no longer 30% higher than the average rate for a specified period. A qualified State remains eligible for benefits for at least thirteen weeks after meeting the requirements. Rates determined by the Secretary are rounded to the nearest one-tenth of 1 percent. National Emergency Grant Assistance for Workers is provided under Section 8. National Emergency Grant Assistance for Workers under Section 8 includes eligibility for grants under the Workforce Investment Act of 1998, allowing funds to be used for employment and training assistance for dislocated workers affected by plant closures or layoffs related to the September 11, 2001 attacks. Additionally, funds can be used for COBRA continuation coverage payments. The Workforce Investment Act of 1998 is amended to allow states to use funds to assist participants in the program by paying up to 75% of their COBRA continuation coverage for a maximum of 10 months. COBRA continuation coverage refers to health insurance provided by an employer under specific laws. The Revenue Code of 1986, ERISA, and section 8905a of title 5, United States Code are amended. $3 billion is authorized for National Emergency Grants related to the September 11 attacks in fiscal year 2002. The amendments made by this section take effect upon enactment.
